status_notes: Case Noted. We apologize for your inconvenience due to the temporary closure of one of the two outbound lanes into Charlestown on the North Washington Street Bridge. Due to recently identified structural safety concerns, the BPWD had started an emergency repair effort on the Bridge.  The required repair is very extensive and therefore also prompted the temporary closure of the outside lane to cordon off the area with many problematic members.  Unseen from the surface, these steel repairs has been performed below the bridge deck since the 3rd weekend in November, and is projected to go on at least to the end of February to mid-March 2018.  During the winter, it is very challenging and time consuming to perform these repairs. The construction project to replace this bridge has been advertised and the bids are to be opened in January 2018. We are extremely excited about the new bridge project, since it is our mission and utmost goal to provide Bostonian a safe and pleasant travel experience. Thanks for letting us know of your frustrations!

description:
Our names are Erica and Michael Lewy. We are BPS parents who live in Jamaica Plain, with our child Hazel Lewy, who attends the BTU Pilot School in the 4th Grade. She's been a student there since K1, and we would hate to leave the amazing community of families, administrators and teachers we've connected with over the years.
The new 9:30 a.m. start and 4:00 p.m. end time at my school will not work for our family. Aside from the fact that a 9:30 start leaves us with nothing to do with our daughter in the morning between the hours of 7:30-9:30 a.m. (current bus pickup time) as both parents in our household work, we have developed a rich after school enrichment program schedule that balances out our child's life. 
She takes theater classes that start at 3:34 with children from all over the area. This cannot be replaced by any on-site programming. Neither of us are able, or willing to remove her early from school classes  early to make it to her theater classes (nor would I hope BPS would want us to) in time to make it for their start. She attends Karate at 4:15 - while this is after 4pm,  there is no way her school bus would be able to get her from school to the site in time. She also attends Kids Arts in Jamaica Plain, which offers a robust variety of activities, such as music, dance, fine arts, cooking, outdoor time, theater and much more. 
Busing can often take 45 minutes or more from the BTU school to her site and 4pm is a heavy traffic period, especially in the area of the BTU school. She will not reach her destination site until 4:3-5pm which cuts out all of the homework time and most of the free play/outdoor time at Kids Arts and cuts into the enrichment activities that I mentioned above.
A child's life is not just schooling. It should not be sitting on buses going from here to there. It should not be inadequate on-site school activities (which has been my experience with on-site care, which honestly is all it is) meant to pass the time in the morning because public school systems are trying to save money.
The BTU Pilot School currently starts at 8:30 am and I see no reason to change it's start time. It falls perfectly in line with research, scheduling and what BPS itself is saying it wants for schools. Why mess with a good thing? 
We understand the intention of later start times for high school students, and the research you’ve used, but not at the expense of our younger students.
The reality is BPS will be spending money, solving the problems that have been just created, to cover the cost of before and after care. 
If schools need more money, let's fight to have private schools pay for their own buses, raise taxes so schools can afford what they need, fight the charters, look to other cities as models (grants such as Seattle, special city buses just for students, school buses that drop off students to more than one school). Stop messing around with our kid's scheduling, stop making up excuses and playing around with algorithms to make things appear scientific. Let's be real. These are kids and families. There are real people involved here. Number crunching isn't going to solve the problems of BPS. If BPS need cash, it needs to be generated. It may be hard but it's not harder than messing around with our families. 

We strongly urge you to halt these proposed start and end times until you have gotten far more feedback on the impacts that such drastic changes will have on the children and families here. 
We intend to continue working together with Boston Public School parents, administrators and teachers until our voices are heard. Families will not back down!
Thank you, 
The Lewy Family
Erica, Michael and Hazel 
(age 9 who is so upset already about the possibility of missing out next year on her after school activities)
BTU Pilot School Family

description: I am a Jamaica Plain resident, former BPS teacher and parent who is against early school start times of 7:15 or 7:30 for elementary or middle school students. This is too early! Students will loose sleep which will be detrimental to their health and learning. Many students will need to spend prolonged hours in after school, which places an undue economic burden on parents. In addition,  they will have less time to spend with their children, especially young children who need more sleep. Furthermore the BPS did not adequately engage parents and the school community in the process of changing school start times. Many families and school communities, including school staff, will be adversely impacted. Let us continue to make Boston a great place to live and not implement these early start times.

description: Still opposed to the new school start times.  For a myriad of reasons. 1) 7:15am is too early for elementary students to be expected to be ready to their best learning.  Just as it is for high school students.  2) Working families.  1:15pm is an absurd time to dismiss students.  That is lunch time, practically.  So many more families will need after school care that hasn't needed it before.  If we are unable to afford or obtain after school care, I will have to stop working.  That option is not viable for my family either, as we struggle to pay our bills as it is.  3) the amount of family time we'll have together will be drastically cut or totally eliminated.  The health and well-being of my children is paramount.  As a household with two full-time working parents, we already experience stress on a daily basis.  This will increase that level and it will negatively impact my children, I know, academically, emotionally, and socially.  Our story is NOT unique.  Not at all.

description:
Please consider the health and educational problems that a 7:15 A.M. to 1:15 P.M. school day will do to my children.

I don't believe that the school department will be able to create "first class" after school programs that are being promised w/ only 9 months to create the programs. I have lived in the city my whole life; it is not practical to believe that a cost effective solution will be in place for after school programming w/o the necessary infrastructure. 

I will not be shame-silenced. I am white as are my kids. This does not mean that I will not stick up for their well-being. I want all children in the city to thrive, but it is imperative that I consider what's best for my children. There is a veiled rhetoric that my "kids will be OK" while others outright  admonish me for putting my children before other lower income children.

I am sorry but I won't be silent if my children's education is being marginalized.

Thank you for taking the time to listen.

description: Thank you Mayor Walsh for addressing parents in West Roxbury today regarding School time changes. No one will relax until you fix this mess. This is not good hard working families that you want to stay in this city. Please freeze this time change plan for now, so that we can all enjoy Christmas!

Please listen to parents across the entire city, the entire district. Pause the start/end change for BPS schools. The process was not transparent. Many minority's still do not know what's going on. Please have translators at all community meetings and really listen to parents now. Really consider what we are saying. Just because we live in Roslindale and my 3 children go to the Patrick Lyndon Pilot school, it doesn't mean I can easily afford afterschool child care. I work part time and hoping to move to full time this summer. My
Boss laughed when I told him I can have a letter from the school committee explaining that 8 would need to shift my hours so that I could pick them up from school. No
One works until 1pm. And my children will not be ready to learn at 7am 5 days a week. They are ages 5, 7& 9. Luckily they do not have disabilities. I can't imagine children that struggle every day at the current time to be suddenly forced to switch their schedule to 2.25 hours earlier.

description:
This letter is in response to the announcement of the school start/end times announced by Tommy Chang this past week. I am writing to voice my concern as a parent to the extreme changes this WILL have to our family and undoubtedly for many families across the City of Boston. First, and most importantly, this change will have dramatic and negative impacts on our family unit. Our 4 year old son, who attends the Gardner Pilot Academy, will lose 1 hour and 15 minutes each morning and this will impact his sleep, nutrition, and ability to effectively and independently regulate himself prior to the start of the day. Due to the inappropriate start time recommended for his school, he will now have 35-minutes from the time he wakes to get himself ready and into his classroom (this includes the time it takes to commute to school). In this case, our family will lose 90-minutes each morning that allows us to function with minimal stress, eat breakfast at a table as a family, and communicate about the expectations of the day before transitioning to the car to begin the 12 minute commute to school. During our 90-minutes each morning, every second is spent supporting the development of vital Activities of Daily Living (ADLs) including, dressing, grooming, feeding, and transitioning. When that time is reduced, one parent WILL need to take the active role in rushing through dressing and grooming increasing stress and reducing our child’s independence. In addition, nutrition will be SO NEGATIVELY impacted as breakfast would need to take place in the back of the car. That means, poor meal choices will occur sacrificing health and mealtime readiness that supports healthy and positive food choices. It is widely known that poor nutrition leads to increased illness, medical instability (changes to vitamin/mineral intake through food sources), rise in obesity, and negative relationships with food. BPS administration appears to be citing limited research supporting later start-times for middle/school and high school children. What they fail to acknowledge is that young child, who are often the most vulnerable in our city, also require 10-12 hours of sleep to develop successful academic readiness skills and positive experiences in the classroom. When the reduction in sleep occurs along with added stress from parents to rush out the door, poor nutrition choices due to convenience, increased financial stress, and longer school days for children who now need to stay in after-school care for a total of 10-11 hours, these children will show less ability to self-regulate both at school and home. This decision shows a lack of concern for ALL families who access education through BPS and a clear trend to appease families at preferred schools such as Boston Latin. It brings to light an underriding question of is this really an opportunity for the CIty to target the School Bus Drivers Union in order to close the budget gap? What will be the City’s response when the MBTA is overburdened with the increase of riders during the 7:30-8:30am rush hour with High School students? How will that be fiscally managed?  The critical point to this drastic change is that the administration should see that NO FAMILY wants a school start time before 8:00am and the residents are clearly asking that the administration work to find a solution to support smart, healthy, positive changes to all school schedules. As a result of these changes our family will spend 5 hours less per week together and most likely need to work on managing negative behaviors in a 4 year old due to lack of sleep.

As a voting resident in Boston, this decision will have STRONG impact on ALL future city elections across all posts and positions going forward. It is vital that the City Council, the School Committee and the Mayor’s office understand the immense effect this has on the future health and vitality of the city and its neighborhoods. Elected individuals and City Councilors who support this decision released by the Mayor, the school committee, and Tommy Chang will be looked at with increased skepticism and scrutiny. The decision and opinion given by each constituent will be tracked and taken into consideration for the next election cycle. People across the Allston-Brighton neighborhood including the GPA community have voiced their disgust with City Council and Mayor Walsh and his elected school committee. This is a city-wide crisis that needs attention and thoughtful consideration. The city is failing its children, teachers, schools, and families. I have never been so disappointed in Boston

I oppose the new school start times/end times. I believe that Supt. Chang is being divisive and disingenuous when he states that this is a racial equity issue. This is a child equity issue.

Supt. Chang now emphasizes new data that the start times are equitable throughout racial backgrounds. This is a disgusting attempt to shut parents up and prevent them from being proponents for their children.

While it always seemed that the new start/end times were intended to save money, Supt. Chang now is attempting to capitalize on past racial division in the city to reinvigorate a social divide, seemingly so that he can quiet parents. Shameful.

My family is white. We are lucky to have supporting families and employment supervisors. However, finances and familial logistics are still difficult for us. I cannot imagine what people of a lower socio-economic backgrounds will be able to do when this untenable plan is implemented. Supt Chang is hurting any racial harmony that might have been gained.

I oppose the new school start times and end times. My children will not be maximizing their educational benefits if they are going to school from 7:15 and ending at 1:15. 

My children (6 years old and 4 years old) would have to be awoken at 6:15 AM. They have not arisen that early since they were babies in a crib.

I would be very impressed if a society of medical professionals or association of educators would disagree with me that 7:15 is an unhealthy and educationally ineffective start time for children, no matter what the child's racial or socio-economic background might be.

-Brendan Kelly
Parent of children at Lyndon School

I'm writing to express my concerns and opposition to the new school start times.  I feel the new times will put working class and working poor families at an extreme disadvantage.  Likewise, I would be hard pressed to get my kids ready and out the door for a 7:15 school start - and they already are in bed by 7pm at ages 5 and 3.5.  Likewise, I have serious concerns about the impact to our neighborhood.  My daughters friends in our neighborhood already all attend different schools, and the staggered end times would make our opportunities to see their pals (via unstructured play or activities) extremely limited.  Our neighborhood community is our top reason for remaining in the city.  If our school moved to a 7:15am start time, we wouldn't hesitate to flee the city.  We were willing to work with the school system but this seems like a slap in the face - why overpay in Boston when you can get more space, more house, and a better school system in some of the nicest suburbs.

Stop the new bell times!
Our names are Laura and Jon Driscoll. We are BPS parents who live in Hyde Park, with our children James (3rd grade at the Haley) and Will (K1 at the Haley), and Lucy (7th grade at BLS).
The new 7:15am start and 1:15pm end time at the Haley will not work for our family because:
-It would be an 11 hour day for our 5 year old because our work schedules do not allow us to pick them up until 6pm.  The proposed offer of writing a letter to our employers is ridiculous and would make zero impact.
-The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that NO child start school before 8am.
-It would mean putting our boys on a bus at 6:30am.  It will often be dark at this hour.
-It would be an increase in cost of the afterschool program.  It is already $194 a week for our 2 boys.  Our family budget cannot bear an increase in costs.  In addition, this program is very poor quality and has high staff turnover.
We understand the intention of later start times for high school students, and the research you’ve used. However our daughter's start time at BLS is only pushed back 15 minutes.  Due to the length of her commute this will not make any impact of the time she needs to wake up in the morning.  
We strongly urge you to halt these proposed start and end times until you have gotten far more feedback on the impacts that such drastic changes will have on the children and families here. 
We intend to continue working together with Boston Public School parents until our voice is heard. 
Thank you, 
Laura and Jon Driscoll

Stop signs are intended to assign right of way and would not be appropriate for speed control on Saratoga St. Please know that federal criteria in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) prevent cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control. Stop signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. With that said, we reviewed the intersection and have upgraded existing signs related to the pedestrian crossings on Saratoga St.

status_notes: Duplicate of Existing Case. Duplicate of Case 101002225921. In order to justify a multi-way stop, an intersection must meet certain criteria outlined in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD). The largest component of the criteria is the number of vehicles that drive through the intersection each hour. We reviewed available traffic data at this intersection, and it does not meet the thresholds to install a stop sign on Oriole Street. The MUTCD also prevents cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control. Stop signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. If residents have specific safety concerns, there may be other solutions more appropriate than adding a stop sign on Oriole Street.
description:
Oriole and wren street West Roxbury 
I observed an accident this evening at this intersection. A stop sign should be added at the oriole st to wren street intersection. There is one on wren st that meets oriole st but in the case of unfamiliar drivers/difficult to see sign in the dark hours the cars coming down oriole come through the intersection rather quickly as they don't currently have a stop sign for added safety.  I've observed this danger during day time hours as well. Unfortunately, tonight it led to an accident. Please consider this suggestion for added safety.
address: Intersection Of Oriole St & Wren St, West Roxbury
